questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with imbalance and a tendency to sway while walking, particularly when turning his head. Neurological examination reveals abnormal vestibulo-ocular reflexes and gait ataxia without limb incoordination. MRI shows cerebellar atrophy localised to the flocculonodular lobe. Which of the following deep cerebellar nuclei is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fastigial nucleus, associated with the vestibulocerebellum, projects to vestibular nuclei and reticular formation, coordinating balance and eye movements via vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal pathways.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (archicerebellum): Regulates equilibrium, balance, and eye movements; receives inputs from the vestibular apparatus; outputs via the fastigial nucleus.
  • Spinocerebellum (paleocerebellum): Controls limb movement and posture; associated with globose and emboliform nuclei.
  • Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum): Involved in planning and timing of movements; output via dentate nucleus.

Explanation of other options:

Globose (Option A): involved in spinocerebellum, not vestibular coordination

Dentate (Option B): motor planning via cerebrocerebellum

Emboliform (Option C): associated with the spinocerebellum

Key Takeaway:

The fastigial nucleus is the deep cerebellar nucleus of the vestibulocerebellum, which is essential for maintaining balance and eye coordination.

questions.text:
Which of the following gait patterns are correctly matched with the corresponding neurological or musculoskeletal condition?
1. Cerebellar disorder - Ataxic gait
2. Basal ganglia - Festinant gait
3. Cerebral palsy - Spastic gait
4. Lower limb injury - Limping gait
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Each listed pairing between the condition and its associated gait abnormality is accurate:

  • Cerebellar disorder → Ataxic gait:
    • Caused by cerebellar dysfunction (especially vermis involvement).
    • Characterised by a wide-based, irregular, unsteady gait with frequent veering or falling.
    • Patients often sway or stagger while walking, resembling a "drunken gait."
  • Basal ganglia → Festinant gait:
    • Seen in Parkinson's disease, a prototypical basal ganglia disorder.
    • Characterised by short, shuffling steps, increased speed while walking, and difficulty initiating or stopping movement.
  • Cerebral palsy → Spastic gait:
    • Spastic diplegia is common in CP.
    • Features include tight hip adductors, toe-walking, and a scissor-like gait pattern due to spasticity.
  • Lower limb injury → Limping gait:
    • Due to pain (antalgic gait), trauma, or structural issues.
    • The patient shortens the stance phase of the painful limb to minimise discomfort, resulting in an asymmetric or limping gait.

choices.text: Arises from the spinal cord and terminates on granule cells
Produces brief depolarisation and generates simple spikes
Arises from the inferior olivary nucleus and directly excites Purkinje cells
Indirectly influences Purkinje cells via parallel fibres

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with gait instability undergoes neurophysiological evaluation. Findings suggest a selective lesion affecting direct excitatory input to Purkinje cells that produces prolonged depolarisation and complex spikes. Which of the following best describes the affected pathway?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus induce complex spikes in Purkinje cells, which are essential for motor learning and error correction in the cerebellum.
  • Each climbing fibre wraps around a single Purkinje cell with ~300 synapses.
  • This is distinct from mossy fibres, which originate from the spinal cord/brainstem, synapse on granule cells, and influence Purkinje cells indirectly via parallel fibres.
  • Mossy fibre input produces brief depolarisation, known as simple spikes.

Explanation of other options:

Arises from the spinal cord and terminates on granule cells (Option A): Describes mossy fibres (spinocerebellar input), not climbing fibres.

Produces brief depolarisation and generates simple spikes (Option B): Simple spikes are produced by mossy fibres, not climbing fibres.

Indirectly influences Purkinje cells via parallel fibres (Option D): Again refers to mossy fiber-granule cell-parallel fiber pathway.

Key Takeaway:

Climbing fibres arise from the inferior olivary nucleus, terminate directly on Purkinje cells, and generate complex spikes, unlike mossy fibres, which act indirectly.

questions.text: A 54-year-old right-handed man presents with difficulty coordinating fine motor tasks like buttoning a shirt and writing with a pen. On examination, his muscle tone and strength are normal. Finger-to-nose test reveals delayed initiation and poor targeting of movement on the right side. MRI shows a lesion involving the lateral zone of the right cerebellar hemisphere. Which functional cerebellar division is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral cerebellar hemispheres constitute the cerebrocerebellum, which interacts with the motor cortex to plan and coordinate skilled voluntary movement.

  • Lesions here impair motor planning, especially for complex, goal-directed tasks.
  • Symptoms are ipsilateral, as cerebellar output crosses twice (via the superior cerebellar peduncle and corticospinal tract).
  • The cerebrocerebellum projects through the dentate nucleus to influence cortical motor programs.

Explanation of other options:

Vestibulocerebellum (Option A): Controls balance and eye movements via the flocculonodular lobe; not involved in motor planning.

Spinocerebellum (Option B): Regulates posture and real-time motor execution through proprioceptive feedback, not motor preparation.

Archicerebellum (Option D): Another name for the vestibulocerebellum related to balance and vestibular reflexes.

Key Takeaway:

The cerebrocerebellum (lateral hemisphere) is responsible for motor planning, and its lesions cause delayed initiation and impaired coordination of fine, goal-directed voluntary movements.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with slurred speech, unsteady gait, and clumsiness in performing goal-directed actions with his right hand. On neurological examination, he has hypotonia, dysdiadochokinesia, and intention tremor on the right side. There is no motor weakness or sensory loss. Which of the following features are classically associated with cerebellar lesions?
1. Dysmetria
2. Hypotonia
3. Resting tremor
4. Intention tremor
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cerebellar lesions impair coordination and timing of voluntary movements, leading to dysmetria, hypotonia, and intention tremor, but not resting tremor.

  • Dysmetria refers to the inability to judge distance or range of movement (overshooting or undershooting a target). (Option 1)
  • Hypotonia results from reduced cerebellar facilitation of gamma motor neuron activity. (Option 2)
  • Intention tremor results from disrupted cerebellar feedback to the motor cortex, leading to oscillatory overcorrections as the limb approaches a target. (Option 3)
  • Resting tremor is seen in Parkinsonism due to basal ganglia involvement, not cerebellar damage. (Option 4)

Key Takeaway:

Cerebellar damage produces intention tremor, hypotonia, and dysmetria, whereas resting tremor is typical of basal ganglia lesions such as Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with uncoordinated movements of his right upper limb. Neurological examination reveals impaired proprioception and ataxia of the arm. MRI shows a lesion in the accessory cuneate nucleus of the medulla. Which of the following pathways is most likely disrupted?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The accessory cuneate nucleus in the medulla is analogous to Clarke's column for the lower limbs, relaying unconscious proprioceptive input from the upper limbs via the cuneocerebellar tract to the cerebellum.
  • Analogous to the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, which serves the lower limb through Clarke's column.
  • Fibres form mossy fibre input to granule cells in the cerebellar cortex, aiding in real-time correction of motor output.

Explanation of other options:

Dorsal spinocerebellar tract (Option A):

Conveys proprioception from lower limbs, not upper limbs; it uses Clarke's nucleus instead of the accessory cuneate nucleus.

Pontocerebellar tract (Option C):

Transmits motor planning signals from the contralateral cerebral cortex to the cerebellum via the middle cerebellar peduncle, not proprioception.

Olivocerebellar tract (Option D): Arises from the inferior olivary nucleus and forms climbing fibres, not mossy fibres; important in motor learning, not direct proprioception.

Key Takeaway:

The cuneocerebellar tract carries unconscious proprioceptive signals from the upper limb to the cerebellum via the accessory cuneate nucleus, entering through the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with complaints of clumsiness in hand movements and difficulty in performing goal-directed actions. During examination, when she is asked to touch an object placed in front of her, she overshoots the target and points past it before correcting her motion. This finding is most consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Past pointing is a clinical test that demonstrates dysmetria, a classical cerebellar sign characterised by an inability to properly estimate the range or distance of a target during voluntary movement.

  • It results in overshooting (hypermetria) or undershooting (hypometria) a target.
  • Dysmetria is due to cerebellar dysfunction affecting movement timing and spatial accuracy.
  • This test is commonly combined with finger-nose or finger-to-finger coordination assessments.

Explanation of other options:

Dysdiadochokinesia (Option B): Impairment in performing rapid alternating movements (e.g., rapid supination-pronation of the forearm), not past pointing.

Finger-nose incoordination (Option C): Finger-nose incoordination is a general term that includes dysmetria and intention tremor, but past pointing specifically tests dysmetria.

Gait ataxia (Option D): Refers to wide-based, unsteady gait; assessed by straight-line walking, not by the past pointing test.

Key Takeaway:

Past pointing is used to test dysmetria, a cerebellar sign where the patient inaccurately judges target distance, often overshooting the mark.

choices.text: Opening of an anion channel by the GABA neurotransmitter causes presynaptic inhibition
The Influx of chloride ions is responsible for presynaptic inhibition
The Gate control theory of pain is an example of presynaptic inhibition

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman suffers from chronic back pain. Neurologic modulation techniques are explored, and she is found to benefit from mechanisms that inhibit neurotransmitter release at the presynaptic terminal of nociceptive neurons. Which of the following statements regarding presynaptic inhibition is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Presynaptic inhibition reduces the release of neurotransmitters from the presynaptic terminal by hyperpolarising it and limiting calcium influx. This is especially relevant in modulating nociceptive signals (pain).

  • GABA-mediated inhibition occurs via:
    • GABA_A receptors, which open Cl- channels → Cl- influx → hyperpolarisation (Option B)
    • GABA_B receptors, which open K+ channels or block Ca2+ channels → decreased neurotransmitter release (Option A)
  • This diminishes excitation of the postsynaptic neuron.
  • The Gate Control Theory of pain involves inhibitory interneurons at the dorsal horn suppressing pain transmission this is a classic example of presynaptic inhibition. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Presynaptic inhibition is mediated by GABA-induced Cl- influx, reducing neurotransmitter release and forming the basis of the Gate Control Theory of pain.

choices.text: It cleaves SNAP-25, which is required for synaptic vesicle fusion with the membrane
It cleaves synaptobrevin, a vesicle-associated membrane protein
It attaches to gangliosides and blocks GABA and glycine release

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with flaccid paralysis, ptosis, diplopia, dysphagia, and dysarthria. He had consumed improperly canned food a day earlier. Microbiological testing confirms infection with Clostridium botulinum. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by inhibiting acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction through cleavage of essential SNARE proteins.

  • Toxins A and E cleave SNAP-25, preventing synaptic vesicle fusion. (Option A)
  • Toxin B cleaves synaptobrevin, another SNARE protein. (Option B)
  • These mechanisms inhibit acetylcholine release, resulting in flaccid paralysis
  • In contrast, tetanus toxin acts in the CNS, binds gangliosides, and blocks GABA and glycine release, causing spastic paralysis.

Key Takeaway:

Botulinum toxin inhibits acetylcholine release by cleaving SNARE proteins (SNAP-25, synaptobrevin), whereas tetanus toxin blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA, glycine) in the CNS.

choices.text: It plays a role in the production of synaptic specificity
Neurexin is a postsynaptic cell adhesion molecule
It helps in synaptic growth and remodelling by acting like neurotrophins
It guides neurotransmitters to bind the postsynaptic receptor directly

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the synaptic protein neurexin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurexin, a presynaptic adhesion molecule, interacts with postsynaptic neuroligin to ensure synaptic specificity for both excitatory and inhibitory synapses during development and plasticity.

  • Neurexin-neuroligin binding is essential for the formation and maintenance of functional synapses
  • Neurexin does not act as a neurotransmitter guide or growth factor
  • Neurotrophins (not neurexins) regulate neuronal growth and remodelling

Explanation of other options:

Neurexin is a postsynaptic cell adhesion molecule (Option B): Neurexin is presynaptic, while neuroligin is postsynaptic.

It helps in synaptic growth and remodelling by acting like neurotrophins (Option C): This is the role of neurotrophins (e.g., NGF, BDNF), not neurexins.

It guides neurotransmitters to bind the postsynaptic receptor directly (Option D): Neurexin is a structural protein; it does not guide neurotransmitter binding.

Key Takeaway:

Neurexin, a presynaptic adhesion molecule, plays a crucial role in synaptic specificity by interacting with neuroligin across the synaptic cleft.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the inhibition of calcium influx in the presynaptic terminal?
1. It prevents the release of neurotransmitters
2. It inhibits synaptic vesicle fusion with the presynaptic membrane
3. It directly blocks the depolarisation of the presynaptic terminal
4. It inhibits the postsynaptic neuron's activity
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The prevention of Ca2+ influx at the presynaptic terminal inhibits neurotransmitter release by preventing vesicle fusion with the presynaptic membrane.

  • Calcium influx is required for vesicle activation and neurotransmitter release. (Statement 1)
  • Inhibition of calcium channels stops vesicle fusion, thereby preventing presynaptic release of neurotransmitters. (Statement 2)
  • Depolarisation occurs due to Na+ entry, and Ca2+ influx follows depolarisation, so it does not block the depolarisation process itself. (Statement 3)
  • Presynaptic inhibition does not directly affect postsynaptic neurons; it only reduces neurotransmitter release into the synaptic cleft. (Statement 4)

choices.text: Reduces the spasticity in cerebral palsy

questions.text: A 28-year-old nurse accidentally administers low-dose botulinum toxin. Under which conditions is low-dose botulinum toxin useful?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Botox contains botulinum toxin, which is a It acts by preventing the release of neurotransmitters in the CNS and at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Local injection of a low dose of botulinum toxin helps in relief from muscle hyperactivity.
  • It can be useful to:
    • Relieve the achalasia by giving an injection to the lower oesophageal (Option A)
    • Its injection into the facial muscles can relieve wrinkles on the face. (Option B)
    • Injection into leg muscles helps to reduce spasticity in individuals with cerebral palsy. (Option C)
  • Botulinum targets SNAP 25 and synaptobrevin to prevent muscle contraction.

Key Takeaway:

Low-dose Botox is useful in:

  • Achalasia
  • Removing wrinkles on the face
  • Reduces the spasticity in cerebral palsy

choices.text: Closure of Na+ channels in phototransduction
Opening of Cl- channels to inhibit glucagon secretion
Opening of K+ channels in the cochlear microphonic potential

questions.text: A researcher studying synaptic inhibition in a neurological patient observes hyperpolarisation. Which process correctly describes inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs) occur when negative ions, such as Cl- or K+, enter the cell, making the inside more negative (hyperpolarised), thus inhibiting action potential generation.

  • In the pancreas, GABA (A receptors) are Cl- channels, and their opening leads to Cl- influx, hyperpolarising the cell and inhibiting glucagon secretion. (Option B)
  • In phototransduction, light causes Na+ channel closure, leading to depolarisation of the photoreceptor, not an IPSP. (Option A)
  • In cochlear microphonic potentials, the bending of stereocilia leads to the opening of K+ channels, causing depolarisation, not inhibition. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

IPSPs occur when Cl- or K+ influx hyperpolarises the neuron. In pancreatic β-cells, GABA (A receptors) open Cl- channels, inhibiting glucagon secretion.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the summation of EPSPs is true?
1. Temporal summation involves repetitive stimulation of a single synapse before the decay of the previous EPSP
2. Spatial summation occurs when multiple presynaptic neurons fire simultaneously
3. A long length constant allows better summation of EPSPs from multiple synapses
4. Temporal summation requires multiple simultaneous synaptic inputs
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A long length constant increases the likelihood that spatially separated EPSPs will summate effectively to generate an action potential.

  • Temporal summation involves repetitive stimulation of a single synapse, not multiple simultaneous synaptic inputs, which defines spatial summation. (Statement 1 & 4)
  • Spatial summation occurs when inputs from different presynaptic neurons summate simultaneously at various dendritic sites. (Statement 2)
  • A long length constant minimises voltage decay, enabling spatially distinct EPSPs to summate more effectively at the axon hillock. (Statement 3)

Key Takeaway:

Temporal summation involves repeated input from the same synapse, while spatial summation combines inputs from multiple neurons.

questions.text: The inhibitory interneurons known as Renshaw cells are activated by motor neurons and project back to inhibit the same motor neurons. This type of inhibitory control is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Renshaw cells are inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord that release glycine.
  • They provide feedback inhibition to motor neurons, helping regulate their excitability.
  • This is a type of postsynaptic inhibition, acting directly on the motor neuron's cell body.
  • When a motor neuron fires, it simultaneously activates Renshaw cells, which in turn inhibit the same motor neuron, preventing overactivation.
  • Presynaptic inhibition, in contrast, involves modulation before the synapse (e.g., GABA-mediated inhibition at afferent terminals). (Option C)
  • Feedforward inhibition is seen in the cerebellum, where excitatory input drives an inhibitory interneuron that suppresses a parallel pathway (e.g., basket cells → Purkinje cells). (Option A)

choices.text: Prolonged if the stimulus is strong
An example of a flexor reflex
Accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding withdrawal reflexes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The crossed extensor reflex, part of the withdrawal reflex, activates contralateral extensors to support body weight, ensuring stability during ipsilateral limb withdrawal.

  • On the ipsilateral side, flexors are stimulated and extensors inhibited, pulling the limb away.
  • On the contralateral side, extensors are activated to support body weight, while flexors are inhibited.
  • Stronger stimuli may recruit more limbs or lead to afterdischarge (sustained response due to polysynaptic circuit persistence).
  • Withdrawal reflexes are classic examples of flexor reflex arcs, triggered by nociceptive afferents (group II, III, IV).
  • Reflexes are graded based on intensity:
    • Mild → Flexor withdrawal
    • Moderate → Crossed extensor reflex
    • Strong → Four-limb response

Explanation of other options:

Initiated by nociceptive stimuli (Option A): Withdrawal reflexes are classically triggered by pain or noxious stimuli.

Prolonged if the stimulus is strong (Option B): Persistent neural activity in interneuron circuits causes an afterdischarge.

An example of a flexor reflex (Option C): The primary action is ipsilateral flexion via the flexor reflex pathway.

questions.text: In an experimental setup, a decerebrate animal with its brain removed and spinal cord disconnected is laid on its side. It exhibits uncoordinated limb movements to attempt rising into a standing position. What is this reflex called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cord righting reflex is a spinal-level reflex seen in spinalized animals, where the animal makes automatic, uncoordinated efforts to assume an upright posture when displaced. It does not require input from higher brain centres.

  • In spinal animals (with chronic transection), local spinal circuits can support complex postural reflexes such as righting movements.
  • Positive supportive reaction: Pressure on the paw activates extension to support body weight.
  • Negative supportive reaction: Stretching on extensors suppresses the support reflex to allow flexibility.
  • Magnet reaction: Light pressure on one side causes limb extension in the same direction.
  • None of these matches the observed reflex of attempting to rise to standing → that's the cord righting reflex.

Explanation of other options:

Positive supportive reaction (Option A): Seen when pressure on the paw causes reflex limb extension to bear weight.

Negative supportive reaction (Option B): Occurs when stretching the extensors inhibits the supportive reflex, not involved in righting.

Magnet reaction (Option C): A reflex where pressure causes the limb to extend toward the stimulus side, not full-body repositioning.

Key Takeaway:

Cord righting reflex is a spinally mediated response where a decerebrate or spinal animal tries to regain standing posture when displaced.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient went to visit the neurologist as advised by the primary care physician. The neurologist checked the reflexes. Here, the knee jerk was found hyperactive on clinical examination. The doctor suspected which of the following diseases was probably?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Descending fibres from higher centres (corticospinal fibres) have a natural inhibitory influence over lower motor neurons. Damage to upper motor fibres leads to an increase in reflex response. Reflexes become hyperactive.

  • Deep tendon jerks are very important tests to examine motor system activity.
  • Motor lesions can be categorised principally into upper and lower motor neuron lesions.
  • The alpha motor neuron is the final common pathway supplying the muscle. It is a lower motor neuron found in the peripheral nerve supplying a particular muscle.
  • Damage to lower motor neurons cannot elicit the reflex response. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in lower motor neuron lesions.
  • Diabetic (Option A) and alcoholic (Option B) neuropathies cause LMN lesions, resulting in reduced or absent reflexes.

choices.text: Primary endings are made from Ia type of afferent fibres
Primary ending responds to the velocity of change in muscle length due to stretch
Primary ending provides information about the speed of movements and allows for quick corrective movements.
Primary endings receive information from nuclear bag fibres only

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the primary endings of muscle spindle afferents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary endings (Ia afferents) innervate both nuclear bag (primarily dynamic, velocity-sensitive) and nuclear chain (static and dynamic) fibres, enabling rapid detection of muscle stretch velocity for corrective reflexes.

  • Primary (group Ia) endings form annulospiral endings and innervate the central region of both dynamic nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibres. (Option A)
  • These are dynamic responders, encoding the velocity of stretch and allowing rapid corrective movements. (Option B & C)
  • In contrast, secondary (group II) endings form flower spray endings and innervate only nuclear chain fibres and static bag fibres, responding to static muscle length.

Key Takeaway:

Primary endings (Ia afferents) innervate both nuclear bag and chain fibres, respond to dynamic stretch, and provide information critical for proprioceptive correction of movement.

choices.text: Dynamic and static responses of muscle spindle afferents influence physiologic tremor
It is of low amplitude and typically has a frequency of around 10 Hz
Prominent dynamic responses help dampen oscillations

questions.text: An 18-year-old medical student develops fine hand tremors just before entering his NEET PG exam hall. He reports that these tremors disappear once the stress resolves. On examination, the doctor explains it is a physiologic tremor. Which of the following is/are true regarding physiologic tremor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Physiological tremor (~10 Hz) is influenced by inferior olivary nucleus oscillations, muscle spindle feedback, and motor unit firing rates, amplified by stress or fatigue.

  • The Ia afferent fibres in muscle spindles respond to both dynamic (velocity) and static (length) changes in muscle stretch.
  • The dynamic response, particularly, helps reduce tremor amplitude by damping the feedback loop, preventing oscillation buildup.
  • The tremor is barely visible, typically low amplitude, with a frequency of about 10 Hz.
  • It may be influenced by factors such as motor unit firing rates, stretch reflexes, resonant properties, and inferior olivary activity.
  • Situational triggers like anxiety before exams can transiently increase physiologic tremor.

Key Takeaway:

Physiological tremor is a benign, normal tremor modulated by muscle spindle afferents, dynamic responses, and cerebellar circuits. It becomes exaggerated in anxiety or fatigue but resolves with rest or reassurance.

choices.text: An Increase in gamma activity reduces the spindle sensitivity.
In pyramidal tract lesions, gamma sensitivity is increased.
Gamma motor fibres help in the regulation of tone and posture
Bulboreticular areas control the gamma activity.

questions.text: Gamma motor neurons play an essential role in regulating muscle activity and proprioception. Which of the following statements is not true regarding their function?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In pyramidal tract lesions, loss of cortical inhibition on bulboreticular facilitatory regions increases gamma motor neuron activity, enhancing spindle sensitivity and causing hyperreflexia.

  • They innervate intrafusal fibres of muscle spindles, keeping them taut during contraction.
  • Increased gamma activity enhances spindle sensitivity, allowing continuous responsiveness to stretch. (Option C)
  • This facilitates stretch reflexes, which are essential for tone and posture.
  • Gamma activity is increased in pyramidal tract lesions, leading to exaggerated tendon reflexes. (Option B)
  • Gamma efferents are regulated by bulboreticular facilitatory regions of the brainstem. (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

Gamma motor neurons increase muscle spindle sensitivity, enabling appropriate reflex tone and postural stability. They are facilitated by the brainstem and become hyperactive in pyramidal tract lesions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with involuntary, writhing, and jerky movements of the limbs. On clinical evaluation, the paediatrician suspects cerebral palsy. Which type of cerebral palsy is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dyskinetic cerebral palsy typically results from perinatal hypoxic-ischemic injury to the basal ganglia, leading to involuntary movements like chorea, athetosis, or dystonia.

Dyskinetic CP:

  • Arises from damage to the basal ganglia or related structures.
  • Movements may be unpredictable, jerky, writhing, or twisting, and worsen with stress or voluntary effort.

Explanation of other options:

Spastic cerebral palsy (Option A): Presents with hypertonia, increased reflexes, and pyramidal tract signs, not involuntary movements.

Hypotonic cerebral palsy (Option C): Rare variant; features hypotonia, floppiness, and may be transitional to other types.

Key Takeaway:

Dyskinetic cerebral palsy involves extrapyramidal motor areas and presents with involuntary movements like chorea or athetosis, distinct from spastic or hypotonic types.

choices.text: Presynaptic and postsynaptic membranes form gap junctions
Synaptic delay is greater in electrical synapses than in chemical synapses
Electrical synapse allows only unidirectional flow of current

questions.text: Which of the following best explains why electrical synapses differ from chemical synapses?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Electrical synapses are specialised connections in which the presynaptic and postsynaptic membranes are joined by gap junctions, allowing direct ion flow between cells, without neurotransmitter mediation.

  • Gap junctions are low-resistance channels that permit rapid, bidirectional ion transfer.
  • This eliminates synaptic delay, making electrical synapses faster than chemical ones. (Option B)
  • Unlike chemical synapses, electrical synapses are not unidirectional; they can transmit signals bidirectionally. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Electrical synapses use gap junctions to allow fast, bidirectional ion transfer, with no synaptic delay, unlike chemical synapses, which depend on neurotransmitter release.
